text:
Aroma, bourbon and more bourboan with a hint of oak.
Appearance, flat cola no head cola color.
Taste, bourbon, oak, vanilla, coconut. Not sure which is predominate as they all seem equal.
Palate, flat cola smooth, sorty heavy.
Overall. Did Barrel aging is a big part of the flavor component bourbon Oak vanilla coconut quite tasty especially if you like bourbon .However, in my opinion The Bourbon Barrel aging process although it adds flavor takes away from the style. You like Bourbon Barrel aged Brew they certainly nailed it thats for a Scottish Wee Heavy not so much.

Outstanding beer. Aromas malty, toffee, caramel, burnt sugar, hint of peat. Flavors mainly sweet, but not too overly so, as its cut nicely by carbonation, peat and a bit of bitter. Excellent body and finish.
Z wczoraj. Karmelkowo-ziemista, nieco zbyt wodnista baza, trochę suszonych owoców, intensywny Bourbon i wanilia. Sympatyczne.
Bottle. Hazy amber brown color, thin light tan head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, tannin, caramel. Taste is sweet bourbon, light to medium body.
From tap. Pours hazy deep hazzlenut brown with a small tan head. Aroma is toasted malty, caramelish. Sweet malty. Toasted and sweet lingering fruity finish.
Bottle - Boozy caramel and barrel notes. Cloudy dark brown withadecent beige head. Boozy sweet caramel with lots of whisky barrel. A bit one sided.

355ml bottle (thx, Yannick!) at Alexs. Pours a hazy copper with a tan head. Aroma is is lots of bourbon, dark fruits, chocolate, boozy. Taste is the same. Very good. Maybe just because I do very like good bourbon barrel aged beers? :-)

Sergeys huntMahogany color, hazy, small head. The aroma is a bit malty, and boozy, bourbon, light tobacco. Moderate malt depth, sweet caramel, strong bourbon vanilla presence, and quite strong booze too. The low bitterness and high alcohol content mean this is not really balanced beer, but its a very good drink.

On tap at Millwrights in Simsbury. Poured a deep mahogany with a small off white head. Aroma of vanilla, molasses, a bit of bourbon. Taste is lightly sweet with fig, cherry, a bit of molasses, some bourbon finish. Very very balanced.. hides the alcohol. Refined. A triumph.
12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head. Aroma of bourbon and caramel malts. Taste is toffee and bourbon.

2016/10/10 - Pours a dark amber brown colour with a thick, frothy, off white head that slowly reduces and leaves ample, patchy lacing. Aroma is lovely; toffee, milk chocolate, bourbon, oak, vanilla and dark fruits. Taste precisely follows nose; vanilla, oaky bourbon, milk chocolate, toffee with hits of cherry and figs. Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with smooth carbonation and a dry, lightly warming finish. Exceptionally balanced, super smooth and hides the ABV surprisingly well. Really nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 9-6-16. Boozy, juicy, dusty aroma features scents of caramel and prune. Not bad but not my favorite set of scents. Pours a clear, dark amber with a small to moderate amount of beige head. Some effervescence in the liquid. Pleasant appearance and nice color but nothing special. Short-lasting head. Decent lacing. Boozy, malty flavor. Caramel and toffee. Waffles with maple syrup. Milk chocolate. Non-tart raspberry. Bourbon flavor noticeable. Sweet yet substantial. Medium to full body. Some liveliness and frothiness in the palate. Bourbon heat, which is good, but otherwise nothing of note in the palate. Im not a big fan of the style (wee heavy). Not a bad beer but doesnt grab me in particular.

Bottle. From parents. Pours a brown color with some particles. Small head. Aroma is vanilla, oak barrel, toffee, bourbon. Medium light sweetness. Warming alcohol. Light carbonation. Taste is similar to aroma. An excellent bourbon barrel aged sipping beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle. Ruby brown with a decent beige head. Aroma is of cherries, peat, fruit cake, bourbon, vanilla, oak, cola and toffee. Taste is of oak, bourbon, cherry, light cola, vanilla, cocoa. Flavors remind me of Jack and cherry Coke.

Bottle. The look is dark and stormy, off white head, and reddish brown in color. The smell is heavyweight, sweet, caramel, fruit, toffee, bourbon, leather. The taste is sweet, but not too sweet, fruit, caramel, cherry, cola, good.

Dark brown with a light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malts, nuts, roast, wood, vanilla, bourbon, alcohol. Taste of caramel, light roast, nuts, vanilla, bourbon, wood, and lighter alcohol in the finish.

Dégustée en compagnie dAlexandre. Liquide pourpre, que je crois être plutôt clair. Une grande quantité de grosses bulles saccrochent au verre et y demeurent accrochées pendant de longues minutes avant de sévanouir. Arômes de fruits noirs, de bourbon et de caramel, le tout en concordance avec le style cest-à-dire, subtiles et jamais trop intenses. En bouche, le liquide est plutôt mince. Un corps qui fait légèrement défaut. Des saveurs délicates de caramel et dalcool chaud. De durée moyenne, une bière bien agréable à boire.

Pours cloudy dark Amber with thin white head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla and oak. Love, love the aroma. Taste is what Id hoped for when I plunked down $7 for one 12oz bottle - bourbon, vanilla, caramel sweetness. Awesome. I see its 12% abv, but no booze in the taste. Smooth, rich, wonderful. Where have you been all my life?

Bottle. Picked a 4-Pack up yesterday on my most recent trip to the 216 to see my girl. In my old stompin grounds back in South Euclid, at Warehouse Beverage (bought my first two cases of used bottles there for homebrewing back in 1989).  Pours a hazy, bronze color with a medium off-white head, solid retention. Nose is boozy barrel, caramel candy, vanilla, figs, dates, candied orange peel. Mouth is medium-full, slick, boozy, candy, some pleasant bitterness, plus everything I mentioned in the nose. It cooled off so its in the 60s tonight, so a decent climate to drink a wee heavy. Awesome. Go Cavs... ALL IN!!!

Reddish brown color, moderate head, good retention, some lace. Aroma is vanilla, caramel, darker bread, toast, toffee, light smoke. Medium to full bodied, somewhat sweet, moderate alcohol in finish with chewy malts. Not bad.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2016 2014 Vintage... Aroma of sherry, vanilla, cherry, oak and a hint of char; deep amber brown color; malty caramel, cherry, bourbon (a bit hot still), just a hint of chocolate; medium body, smooth, pleasing carbonation, slightly milky; aging nicely, very good and mellow, would like more smoke. 12 fl oz bottle.

Tap Hollywood. Like a dark iced tea in color. First taste is big and beefy. Beer soaked with 2 shots of bourbon. Not sure if I get these beers. If I want a boiler maker, Ill order one. Oh, this is so volatile, its so freakin boozy. Simply too big for this lager lovin sissy. Finish is, just think for yerself, this is a 12% beer? Not impressed. This is an insult to Scotch ale, unless that is, if you want to get a little dizzy on one beer.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: A very good, tasty scotch ale. Pours a beautiful bright red with a tan head. Smells of red wine, bourbon and vanilla, as well as cola. Taste is quite smooth and sweet, with lots of bourbon and vanilla, and some scotch ale sharpness in the finish. Had in the bottle.

Aroma caramel, butterscotch, dark fruits, woody, vanilla, 
Appearance brown, cloudy, 
Taste medium sweetness, 
Palate medium body, 
Overall so smooth like a fine bourbon on the rocks. Not one thing sticks out with this beer. It is so well balanced. Some wood, caramel sweetness, and a nice bourbon that is all the way through. I would suggest this beer to a friend.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, dark reddish brown pour with khaki colored head, aroma brought notes of dark fruit, caramelized sugars, hints of nice bourbon note with some oak, more vanilla/sweet sugar notes with some slight smoke, dark cocoa notes. Taste was a mix of dark fruit, vanilla, slight spicy notes, hints of oak, slight spice, finishing sweet. Well integrated, no booze comes through.

bottle @ Party Source / Bellevue KY --- Aroma of earthy toasted caramel malt. Hazy amber brown color, beige head, sheets of lace. Taste is solid caramel malt with strong alcohol warmth lurking in the background. Light fizz on the swallow, a little vanilla along the way, but mostly caramel and alcohol. Would be better listed as an Abbey Quad, or something similar, because Scotch Ale implies something strong, but less sweet. Overall, it works, but a full bottle is a little much for me.

Tap at The Well, New York. Colour is reddish brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Ripe fruits, some sweetness, some distant hints of alcohol, caramel and malts. Simple but I like these kind of beers.
Bottle to glass. Pours a medium to deep brown with some reddish hues. Aroma is boozy, scotch, light smoke. Flavor is toffee, caramel, vanilla. Nice barrel presence. Solid.

Sweet bourbon aroma fills your nose. Sweet malts and bourbon fill your mouth, with the 12% warming it. The sweetness is a molasses type that's just a little too sweet.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Medium/strong, bold aroma of plum, cherry and bourbon. Dark amber/brown color with small/medium light beige head and hazy liquid. Strong averagely balanced taste with plum, bourbon, cherry, some vanilla and coffee and a hint of licorice. Complex taste with wide taste spectrum and medium aftertaste with clear malty bourbon. Strong body with medium/low carbonation. Overall, schoolbook like taste except not perfectly balanced and could have either more body or less carbonation. Great performance though.

December 30, 2015 - bottle from Brett. Dark brown pour with some head that foamed up nicely with a gentle swirl. Aroma was bourbon, sweet malt, wood and dark fruit. Taste was consistent with aroma, but heavy with the wood.

Tallahassee, FL - ABC Fine Wine & Spirits - 12 oz bottle. Very dark, dense orange/light brown pour, not much of a head. Aroma has some toffee accents, a hint of molasses, just a touch of bourbon. Flavor is decidedly sweet, toffee, date sweetness, some prunes, a touch of molasses, just a hint of bourbon in the back end. Thick, sticky mouthfeel.

12 oz undated bottle (thanks BH) served in a Belgian snifter after warming to a temperature a bit higher than the recommended 43F.

Pours fairly clear but the dark red-brown body is nearly opaque in the glass. Semi-durable tan head leaves decent lacing. 
Aroma ripe and dried dark fruits, bourbon, faint baked grains. 
Flavor: similar to the aroma with a touch of added vanilla and some wood notes that appear in the finish and aftertaste. Lightly sweet. 
Feel: admirably smooth with well hidden alcohol but some inevitable warming.

Poured into a snifter.

2.75 A: Deep brown color. Just a thin skin of head formed during an aggressive pour and fell just as quickly as it formed.

4.0 S: The bourbon and barrel mix extremely well with the base beer. Big leathery component with molasses, melon, plum, raisin, and caramel. A touch of smokiness, a bit of roast, vanilla, oak.

3.75 T: Taste is like the nose. Leather, molasses, plum, raisin, caramel, smoky peat. Roast vanilla, oak. Id prefer it to be a bit thicker and perhaps a bit sweeter, but its still pretty good.

3.0 M: Heavier medium body. Undercarbonated by about half of what Id want. Lightly creamy, which I imagine would be improved with more carbonation.

3.75 D: Pretty good beer. Only complaint is that Id love some more carbonation.

★ 768 characters


DavoleBomb, May 14, 2014
12oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Sharp spirit flavors. Lots of spices, and some caramel.

Pours a murky brown body with a 1/4th inch off white head. Head retention is good and lacing is great. 

Smell is of burnt brown sugar, caramel malt and charred oak. As beer warms, bourbon becomes more apparent. Hops werent detected. 

Taste is definitely a malt bomb. Biscuit malts, caramelized sugar, and burnt oak dominate the palate. Bourbon is definitely in there but isnt too harsh for a 12 percent alcohol beer. 

Mouthfeel is medium heavy, carbonation is a tad on the low end. Head was present throughout the beer and added a nice amount of creaminess. 

Overall beer was good but malt and sweetness were overpowering. Would have liked something to distract from the cloying sweet malt, maybe more barrel aging?
Bottle - Pours a caramel color. Nose is bourbon, vanilla, oak, toffee, caramel, and sweet. Taste is nice caramel and toffee notes followed by bourbon and vanilla. Thick mouthfeel. Very smooth.

Bottle, thanks sevenhokie! Absolutely wonderful caramel malt aroma with whiskey, vanilla and some oak notes. Pours dark caramel brown colored with a thin white head the dissipates quickly and no lacing. Starts with rich, sticky sweet caramel malt flavors with a nice full body and mouthfeel. Finishes incredibly smooth with excellent vanilla, whiskey and oak flavors. Absolutely amazing!
Sample. Amber color with red tint. Off white head. Bourbon, sweet caramel candy aroma. Taste is similar, very smooth and the alcohol is hidden well.

Deep reddish amber color out of the bottle with a short creamy beige head. Lots of the bourbon barrel in the nose with some smokey grains and caramel candy. This drinks as a big, boozy beer with lots of caramel sweetness, ripe fruit, smokey peat and burnt sugar. Some buttered burnt toast and a bit of butterscotch. Really quite an interesting brew.

Ive been waiting to try this, but not waiting long. Thats a good thing. I have bottles Ive waited on for a year, and I know thats not long to some of you out there, but its like putting ice cream in front of a child and then saying "no...you cant have it! This has only been in the vicinity of my taster for a month. Im drinking it NOW. Yay me!
The beer is opened and the malty fluid pours into a tulip as requested by the brewer. The aroma is dark caramel, peat smoke and wood; the scents melding warmly above the glass. The dark, ruby-amber beer is topped with a finger of khaki foam that thins to a deep ring at the glass and forms a sheet across the surface. A deep inhalation draws the brew to life, and as I bring the glass to drink, the heady sweetness causes my eyes to close. Surely the lack of one sense will allow me to better experience the depth of the others! I tip the glass to pull the brew over my tongue and find a dry bite at the tip of it, though not from the heat of the beer. This isnt boozy, in fact, quite the opposite; Im experiencing the sweetness of malt and burnt sugar tempered with bourbon...very nice! The cool brew is sticky on my lips, a luscious liquid exhibiting intoxicating aromas. Ive come to love this style because of the thick, sultry way it warms, the way it slips over your tongue and down your throat before you realize that it was even there, and then its gone, and you want more! The Wulver Im experiencing is savage in sweetness, but this is tamed by the age, by the bourbon accents. The finish is long on it because of that stickiness, but the flavor is consistent, so I dont mind. This is a really nice beer. I should have bought two. Maybe three. If it was local, Id always have a bottle on hand. No doubt.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a dark mahogany with white head. Incredible robust aroma of caramel, bourbon, toffee, butterscotch, roasted nuts. Taste is very complex. Moderate to heavily sweet with minimal bitterness. Flavors of bourbon, caramel, toffee, figs, nuts, butterscotch, maple syrup, dark fruits. Definitely one of the best scotch ales. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark mahogany with a light white foam head. Aroma is lots of bourbon and some caramel. Flavor is sweet caramel and bourbon, with a creamy smoothness to the mouthfeel. This is very good.

Somewhere between a 2 and 4oz bottle pour at SAVOR 2015s Saturday night session. Poured a cloudy dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma was nutty, caramel, chocolate, roasted, toasted. Lots of smooth caramel, vanilla and butterscotch. Delicious.
2-4 oz bottle pour at SAVOR 2015s Saturday night session. Dark brownish color. Aromas of caramel, bourbon, caramel. Tastes of same with some light booze. Medium body with a dry finish. Great stuff.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle. 
Aroma is quite nice with a lot of caramel and toffee. Light chocolate notes with a moderate nuttiness. Some moderate raisin and fig notes with a light oak and medium light bourbon note. Hints of the alcohol. Some toasted bread. 
Pours a fairly clear burnt Amber brown with a small, moderately thick, tan head that recedes fairly quickly to the edge where it lingers. 
Flavor is moderately sweet with a lot of caramel and lighter toffee notes. Lighter chocolate and a hint of roast. Medium raisin, light fig and prune. Medium toasted bread with some light nuttiness. Light oak and medium light bourbon notes with a hint of alcohol spice. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. Honestly, it feels a bit thin. 
Overall, a really nice aroma and flavor. Less bourbon and oak than I was expecting. Fairly well attenuated which is nice, but not quite thick enough (I know this is contradictory). The malt presence is nice and complex.
Aroma ok, best for all other, color come with dark red brown, thin crown, close your eyes and you see its barrel when taste

Notes from Scotch Ale tasting for St. Patricks Day. Reddish brown pour with no head. Aroma has faint whiskey, light brown sugar. Taste is sugary with toffee and whiskey. Later on re-review, fuller body than most with solid components. A bit surprisingly this was the winner of the competition, beating Alesmiths Wee Heavy, Founders DBast, and others, and all agreed a very solid choice.

Bottle. Raisin/dried cherry, caramel malt and alcohol aroma. Dark chestnut brown with small but long lasting light tan head. Very sweet vanilla, raisin, caramel, biscuit malt, and bourbon flavor. Nice balance and body. A bit on the sweet side but still very nice - will let the rest age for a while.

Caramel pour with minimal head. Toffee, maple syrup, vanilla, dark fruits in the lovely aroma. Full bodied. Delicious. Melted caramel, vanilla, oak, ripe fruit, sweet malt, and a bit of booze. The booze is mostly hidden and only accentuates the profile. Fantastic Scotch ale.
UPDATED: JUL 24, 2015 This beer is a good as any great American beer of any type. Do your self a favor hunt this beer down and enjoy a Great Amrican WEE HEAVY!

Bottle. The pour is a dark copper color. The aroma has a nice booziness to it that is inviting. The taste is big up front then mellows in the end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Torst, Brooklyn. Toffeish vanilla aroma. Medium to full bodied. Lots of vanilla from bourbon barrel. Toffeish malty flavor. Liquerish palate. Hides alcohol very well without being overly sweet. Not the most complex barrel beer but good.

From bottle aged 1-1.5 years. Deep murky black/brown pour with a really dizzy light brown head that quickly dissipated. Bright blended whiskey aroma, vanilla, fresh canvas. Soft carbonation, tingly oily mouthfeel, really great clean effervescent finish. Lots of blended whiskey flavor, vanilla and oak are subtle and welcome, some weathered wood, malted milk ball too. Really great BBA beer and great scotch ale.

An opaque brown body with a than head that had nice retention and lace. Aroma was a great mix of caramel and smoked malts. Rich notes of oak, vanilla and bourbon complemented it Flavor was initially sweet, bourbon was present but not overpowering. A nice mild smokiness. A sweet finish with just a hint of molasses in the after taste. Full bodied.

This is insanely good. Aromas are so memorable. Beautiful bourbon, oak, brown sugar, bread, dark fruit, caramel. Nice sweet vanilla and bourbon flavors. Caramel and a touch of booze. Probably the best scotch ale Ive had. World class stuff.

12 ounce bottle purchased in Manhattan (Whole Foods at Columbus Circle) and enjoyed in my hotel room while on a business trip to NYC ($6.99). Pours a lazy brown-copper hue with one finger of off-white foam. Really nice AROMA of rich toffee, chocolate chip cookie dough, nutty vanilla, bourbon notes, butterscotch, and molasses. FLAVOR of boozy bourbon, vanilla, light chocolate, thick caramel, and dark bready malts. Finishes with some sweet booziness. "Wee heavy" is an appropriate descriptor here as the big 12% never actually feels that big in the mouth. Not quite up there with Alesmiths beautiful BA Wee Heavy, but still an excellent and readily drinkable of the style. Would like to see more breweries barrel age their wee heavies. (168, 947)
its difficult to barrel age non stouts and sours, this is an example of why, tons of boubon flavors and nothing else, the base is demolished. Some sweetness sitting around there for sure.
on tap poured into a tulip glass..ruby/amber color with fluffy white head..aroma of dark fruits,vanilla,oak,bourbon,caramel..tastes like it smells..boozy in a good way..very good.

bottle shared by mathieuc, thanks bro! pours unclear dark brown with a small reviving light beige head, nice lacing sticking. sweet caramelized roasted nuts, coconut and obvious bourbon - some bananas too, tia maria *TM, burnt caramel, tannins, spices and pepper. average to light carbonation, medium to full body - oily and syrupy; sweet and gently woodsy finish. big. still.. nice stuff.

Bottle 12oz.
Pours brown/very dark amber with very low light-beige "head". Aroma is of intense bourbon, nuts, alcohol. Taste is of bourbon, sugar, acid. Palate: Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Sticky on the lips. Overall: Good, boozy. Lots of bourbon.

Bottle (12 oz). Split 2-ways with the lady. From cparles, thanks! 

Appearance: Dark brown with a small quickly disappearing off-white head that leaves some lacing. 

Aroma: Bourbon is dominant along vanilla, caramel, toasted malt and moderate fruitiness. Alcohol too, but not overpowering.

Taste: Bourbon, vanilla, toasted malt, caramel, anises, fruits and alcohol.,, all coming along quite nicely. Medium sweetness. 

Palate: Full bodied. Moderate carbonation. Oily mouthfeel. Fruity and warming finish. 

Overall: Well balanced Scoth Ale. The bourbon/vanilla, caramel and fruitiness are all well integrated. Its quite tasty and its not too hot for a 12% abv beer. Decent sweetness level for the style. Very good.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2015 Pours a dark brown with a small white head that leaves good lacing. Nose is of caramel, moka, wood and coconut. Taste is of coconut, moderately sweet and not too boozy. Flavors play on the chocolate and coffee theme, not what I am expecting from a scotch ale but it was really flavorful so its OK? Some vanilla and dark fruits. Body was medium-full, carbonation low and mouthfeel sticky/syrupy. Overall a nice beer but it drank more like an american imperial stout than a wee heavy in the end.

12 oz bottle, with thanks to Homer. Enjoyed during the first half of the NCAA football national championship game. I dont really have a horse in this race, but Big Ten allegiance means the first half beer is brought to you by Ohio. Well see if my PacNW leanings come out later. But, I digress. Poured at cellar temperature, this looks exactly like cola. What little head was present on the pour dissipated immediately. Aroma: chocolate, cherries, dark fruit, bourbon. Taste: I expect this to be syrupy sweet, but it dries out on the end (presumably due partly to oxidation). Malt-driven, sweet and fruity, but never cloying. Alcohol is well-concealed. Muted cola syrup character. Palate: Fully body, soft carbonation, slick smooth texture. Alcohol on the tongue. Overall: yum. I should have saved this for a blind RB BA scotch ale tasting, but, you know, football. At any rate, glad to have the full bottle to myself. The first couple of ounces I would have given this a 3.8, but by ounces 4-6 this has opened up nicely. The flavor lingers so nicely. I admit Im a sucker for strong sweet dark beers, and this presses that button real nice, but crafted so well that I dont even feel guilty giving it a high score.
Aroma of bourbon and malt, taste is heavy bourbon, very malty, caramel, toffee, alcohol. Very similar to Backwoods Bastard.
Bottle from NYC. Dark brown body with a small offwhite head. Bourbon, malt, caramel, light alcohol notes, dark fruit, raisin, plums. Nice sipper.

Just not really my style but I understand the hype. Boubon really overwhelms this beer. Had it on draft. Very fresh and tasty just not where my pallet goes when in thinking beer. Maybe a cigar, a fire, and a leather chair type of beer.
Not impressed, imagine a watered down founders backwoods bastard without the complexity look at other reviews for flavor breakdown, its just not worth it
Pours a dark maroon with light white head. Has a strong dark fruit, cherry, malt, and dark alcohol aroma. A strong dark fruit malt and dark alcohol flavor with some wheat. A dry aftertaste.

Bottle courtesy of Winter Santa 2014/2015. Thank you RobertDale! Pours deep dark wooden brown with a rather small creamy beige head that leaves some trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet and malty with caramel, toffee, vanilla fudge, charred wood, roasted coconut, bourbon alcohol and moist soil. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter, malty and very tiny fruity with sweet dark bread, caramel, toffee, vanilla fudge, raisin bran, charred wood, moist soil, prunes, caramelised almonds, roasted coconut, baked pears, bourbon alcohol and orange zest. Mouthfeel is soft, round, tiny viscous, slightly boozy and medium to full bodied. Finish is sweet and tiny bitter with caramel, toffee, vanilla fudge, raisin bran, charred wood, baked pears, roasted coconut, hay and bourbon alcohol. The label says it was made for bourbon ageing and I agree. Basically a nice malt base and base beer with a huge barrel presence. What a nice decadent way to start off the new year!

12 oz bottle, tulip. Little head to speak of at first, then no head. Deep reddish brown. Massive bourbon barrel aroma, in fact this should just be called bourbon barrel ale. Ton of woody vanillin goodness. Delicious - rare BA beer that gives BCBS a run for its money. Ill have to have another Backwoods Bastard to be sure but I think this is better (for what thats worth, both being great beers). An underappreciated beer, better than the BA Siberian Night, and one I wish I would have procured more of. If youre suffering BCBS withdrawal but can find this, by all means find it.

On tap at Tørst in Brooklyn, served in a stem glass. Pours clear reddish-brown with a small, tan head that fades and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has big raisin, brown sugar, figs and oak, along with earth, vanilla and bourbon. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with raisins, figs, dark pit fruit, brown sugar, vanilla with oak and bourbon notes. The finish is long and oaky, with vanilla, bourbon and brown sugar. On the palate, it is medium-full with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, wow, an incredibly complex brew. A beautiful bourbon barrel-aged wee heavy. 2014-12-05

Sample tap at Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh. This is a perfect brew but I took of a digit just because there has to be something wrong with it ---- I just dont know what it is. Youll seriously think your drinking straight bourbon before you think its just a beer. Run and get it before its gone.

Bottle thanks to Guinn. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is malty sweetness oak bourbon vanilla slight chocolate. Just wonderful. Flavor follows with slight alcohol present. Rich mouthfeel. Really nice beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Rattle N Hum. Awesome bourbon aroma with vanilla, oak, dark fruits and some boozy character. Dark coppery amber clear with thin head. Medium-heavy body with medium-heavy carbonation. Warming. Starts and stays sweet, rich but not overly complex. Bourbon finish with smooth after and alcohol warming. Nice ale.

Bottle. Dark ruby with very little head. Aroma is booze, caramel, vanilla and oak. Taste follows and adds a hint of butterscotch and creme brûlée. Medium sticky mouthfeel and long finish. Tasty and aggressive.

It pours dark brown with a creamy light brown head that produced moderate lacing. It has a heavy aroma of bourbon, alcohol, caramel. and hints of vanilla. The caramel and bourbon are first on the tastes, the a warming sensation with vanilla notes. It is somewhat sweet as well.
Spotty lacing. Aroma of dark fruit, malt and oak. Rich, syrupy body with flavors of earthy malt, fruit, caramel and oak. The finish is oaky vanilla with a lingering bourbon aftertaste.

Bottle poured a clear reddish amber with a lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of bourbon, toffee, oak, caramel, dried fruit and light vanilla. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bourbon, toffee, caramel, light fruitiness and a hint of vanilla with a smooth lingering bourbon finish.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2015 Pours a medium dark brown with thin beige head. Aromas of alcohol, sweet fruit and whiskey. Taste is smooth with roasty bitterness and bourbon essence. Overall a little thinner than I expected. Nice and drinkable but not offensively big like expected for price. I like it, but not a must try.
12oz bottle to snifter. Clean medium brown pour. Light malt strong booze aroma. Thin ring. Ridiculous sweet. Huge barrel. Syrupy.

12 oz bottle, poured into a snifter at room temperature.

A: Pours into the glass a cloudy, opaque deep hickory brown, and forms a nice pale head that slowly settles into a thick cap and ring. Shining light through the beer reveals a ruby-red cloudiness, and some bubbles slowly rising.

S: Heady caramel and toffee toast malts, twined around a boozy, warm hardwood and vanilla waft out of the glass. The scent is plenty sweet, and contains little surprises here and there, like a tiny touch of anise or a bit of raisin.

T: That is a smooth, smooth barrel-aged wee heavy. Sweet as can be, caramel and toffee and fresh dark bread, all aglow with the warmth of oaky bourbon. Vanilla and raisin play along the edges of the flavor profile, along with some faint shadows of leather and figs. The finish is a quick blast of bourbon, followed by a lingering caramel-toffee sweetness tinged with vanilla. Alcohol heat settles in the belly, not in the mouth.

M: Since "perfect" is not actually all that descriptive, Ill try to be a little more detailed. This is a full, rich, creamy-smooth beer, the sort that feels like you can fold it with your tongue. It clings to the teeth and tongue rather well, and has just the right amount of carbonation for me not to notice it at all without the beer feeling flat.

O: This may be the single best execution of an aged wee heavy I have ever had, including the Founders Backwoods Bastard. Incredibly easy to drink, allows the malty sweetness to star with the bourbon barrel as the supporting cast, hides the ABV well - this is a really well done beer.
Pours mahogany with tan head and very little lacing. Aroma of bourbon, chocolate, aged malts, wood, and vanilla. Taste is the same with some soy sauce. Silky with a good kick. Very nice!

Bottle at home. Pour is deep murky brown with a small tan head and decent lacing. Sweet caramel, bourbon, toffee, coconut, wood, some cocoa, light roast, and brown sugar in the aroma. Taste is big coconut, brown sugar, raisins, plums, light roast, wood, and dates with a semi-sweet finish. Slick mouthfeel with low carbonation. Sweet, rich and full of flavor. Nice stuff.

36cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2011, thx alot to Jef for sharing!, complex Scotch, alcoholic/sweet and slightly malty/woody, yet not too heavy, balanced, hazy, nearly no head, good Winter brew

Bottle from a trade. Thanks! Brown colour, minimal beige head. Medium carbonation. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, marzipan and lots of bourbon. Sweet with light bitterness. Malty body. Ok, but a bit too sweet.

Bottle. Pours a reddish brown with a thin off-white head that left spotty lacing. Aroma of sweet bourbon, caramel, vanilla, oak and toffee. Flavor was a nice blend of bourbon with rich toffee, caramel, vanilla, oak, and dark fruit. Medium-full body, soft carbonation, silky smooth texture

Bottle shared with the crew @BSP. This is what a bourbon barrel beer should taste like if you really like bourbon. The caramel and maltiness of the base beer comes through beatifully in the vanilla, oak and booze of the barrel aging with a hint of raisin. Really nice.

Bottle: Dark caramel colored body with clarity only at the edges; creamy, beige head on top that takes its time slowly sifting downwards. Head first whiskey aroma. Jack & Coke... minus the Coke. Sugary, maple tinted charcoal, oak staves, stinging toffee, & a big batch of dark fruit lightly dusted in brown sugar. That booze, though. Luckily its not as poignant on the palate. Not sure how or why, but Im not complaining. Burnt brown sugars, caramel, dates, light cocoa powder, rich oak slabs, reminders of vanilla, smooth(er) whiskey warmth. The booze is, of course, very noticeable, but not unmanageable, though it does gain some steam as the beer warms up. Sticky, pretty thick body, what youd expect from a Scotch ale. I think this one is a little overrated, perhaps? Needs to mellow out a bit. Otherwise, still a good beer.

12oz bottle in a tulip. Pours deep brown with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of caramel and toffee and nutty malts, bourbon and oak and vanilla, some dough, and light bitterness. Flavor the same with the strong malts and bourbon and oak dominating. Average to smooth texture. A cool beer, but could be slightly more balanced.

A wee heavy ale aged 11 months in a bourbon barrel. This has a really strong bourbon taste. It also has a sweet start without a bitter finish. Tasted on 4/6/2014. Picked up for $ 6.24 per 12oz bottle.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma of bourbon, malt, and caramel. Taste is bourbon, malt, caramel, vanilla, and wood. It is a touch hot. Excellent.

Bottle. Pours brown with red hues, off-white head. Aroma is strong bourbon, figs , raisin, rich, desserty. Taste is chocolatey, bourbon, vanilla, espresso finish, medium bodied but do flavorful. This is a great, easy drinking brew with tons of complexity and flavor!!!

12oz bottle form Andersons on Bent Tree. Deep mahogany pour with a thin light tan head. Aroma of sugary sweet, bourbon, toffee. Tastes follow suit with lots of caramel, whiskey, vanilla, oak, light spice. Really big up front and then mellows through the burnt sugar finish. Well made, if not my thing generally.

Bottle thanks to fishmich! Pours clear ruby mahogany with a small tan head that dissipates fairly quickly to a ring with some lacing. Aroma is bourbon, dark sugars, vanilla. Flavor is bourbon, oaky vanilla, medium sweet, light bitter and fairly tannic. Lightish body, low carbonation, some ABV burn, but not bad for 12%
Almost black pour. Small light tan head. Not much lacing. Huge malty and bourbon aroma with some grain. Caramel notes as well. Taste is caramel and booze. Very hot.

12 oz. Nose is vanilla, caramel, whiskey and a touch of chocolate. Pours a clear mahogany with a lasting spit of bubbles. Flavors of chocolate, vanilla, whiskey and caramel. Some light toasted oak in the finish. Medium-heavy body has low-medium carbonation and is to the sweet side. Excellent dessert beer.
Coffee mug. Black pour with some head. Some light scotch, oak and barrel aromas. Some vanilla, oak, toffee flavors, very mild.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Murky brown. Floral, marmalade-molasses aroma that becomes vinous, vinous a little sweet taste. A little fizzy, full-bodied, syrupy, long, sweet peachy finish.
A solid scotch ale, which I am not usually a big fan of. Thirsty Dog is becoming a staple brewery that I continue to stockpile their beers in my cellar.

From notes. Enjoyed at the Ashleys Rare & Vintage Beer TasteFest on June 07. The pour is a deep ruby with a thin ring of off-white head and no lace. The aroma is pretty damn good. There is a strong bourbon-y vanilla up front and a delightful addition of woodiness. There is a nice malt profile with a little toasted caramel and maybe a little sweetness. The flavor is a little more reserved, and the earthiness seems much more prevalent, drowning out some of the subtleties that the nose offers. The mouth feel is light, but the good carbonation helps it coat the mouth. The aftertaste is good; earthy, malty, and lingering.

12 oz. bottle via local trade. Pours a deep, clear mahogany color with a minimal off-white head. Aroma of bourbon, toffee, brown sugar, vanilla, caramel, charred oak, and peat. The flavor is the same, but sweeter, and with a smooth tea note. Medum-bodied, with low to moderate carbonation and a smooth, sweet mouthfeel. Really decadent, rich aroma that the flavor doesnt quite match. Still, this is an upper-tier barrel-aged Scotch ale.

Poured an amber dark brownish color with aromas of booze, bread, malt, wood and more bourbon. Flavors are a mixture of the aroma light nuts thrown in aromas well. Lots of booze in the flavor aromas and aftertaste.

12 oz bottle. Pours a translucent dark brown/plum color with reddish hues when backlit. One finger of head fades quickly to a lasting wisp of head on meniscus with minimal lacing. Aroma is sharp and pleasant: bourbon, malt, and caramel sweetness. Flavor is same with more oak and vanilla notes. Tobacco notes in the finish; active carbonation distracts from an overall thin mouthfeel. Terrific.

Beer shared by RussianDragon. Thanks Dave.

The beer is chestnut brown with a thin beige collar. The aroma brings a huge dose of bourbon, followed by malt, brown bread, oak. Bourbon steals the show. Delicious flavor, following the aroma. An almost tannic character. The aroma is the star of the show here. Thin body with a light feel on the palate. A touch of spice with a hearty malt body. Very tasty.

Clear ruby-tinged brown, thin white head. Raisin bran, toffee, figs, a little vanilla, cocoa powder, and herbal tones. Brown sugar sweetness jarred by a strong bitterness. Light carb, full-bodied, and a bit of astringency. Almost moderate booziness in the bitter finish.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Pours brown to orange with a beige head, aroma of bourbon, wood, scotch, dried fruits, flavoris sweet with wood, bourban, vanilla, coconut, dried fruits, full bodied, Great

Bottle via trade with JStax  thanks! Dark brown and light mahogany in color, a thin beige head fizzes out before my first sip. The nose on this dog is outstanding! Bourbon, vanilla, caramel, and chocolate swirl together. Nice symmetry and rich. Not hard to score this a 10. Not hard at all. Good transition to the taste; the same aforementioned blend along with light esters and butter toffee. Maybe a hint of oak. The finish isnt heated, but the high abv is easily detected. I wish it werent so potent, but I guess as a sipper it doesnt really make that a negative. Im really impressed with this; it hits nearly every mark for me.

Clear dark brown pour with a thin tan head.
Complex aroma; bourbon, brown sugar, raisin.
The flavor follows the aroma, The bourbon is nice not under or over done.
Nice Scotch ale.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Deep amber to brown. Lovely aroma of bourbon, vanilla, malt, caramel, some cookies and a bit of chocolate. Sweet flavor, a bit boozy, with bourbon, vanilla and cookies. Full-bodied, rounded chewy mouthfeel. Very good.

Bottle. Not old. Pours hazy hazy brown with not much head. Aroma is all bourbon, vanilla and milk chocolate. Flavor is similar with lots of booze throughout but not enough to balance out the cloying sweetness. Bitterness only just peaks through at the end. Feel is fairly thick and oily with some liveliness. Really not into this bourbon sugar bomb.

Bottle from bestway. First sip is that flat cola flavor i love in a scotch ale. The bourbon comes through in the aroma and flavor a little as it warms. The vanilla complements the cola well as coke discovered in the 90s with vanilla coke. Is that a little bit of spice as it warms further? Very interesting and complex.
Bottled. Brownish reddish pour. Pretty boozy. Malt flavor with vanilla oak caramel. .
bottle from ? in trade. forgot my damn notes. Good, not top scotch ale is the summary... stalling....

Pours a deep amber with white head and light sticky lacing .... Aroma of caramel malts, vanilla, light coconut, oak and very slight hints of bourbon .... Taste is of sugary caramel malts, light coconut, oak, some bourbon notes that linger into the finish and vanilla with some peated malt evident .... Finish is of bourbon and sweet caramel malt with a light bitter bite .... Mouthfeel is thin ... Very good stuff
Caramel with a cream head. Vanilla, light peat, smoke, vanilla and sweet. Great palate, caramel, vanilla, rich malts, toffee, nice finish.

From bottle. Pours a murky brown with a thin light beige head. Aroma of caramel and bourbon. Huge caramel, malts, and light bourbon flavors come from this beer. The huge alcohol content is well-hidden. Full mouthfeel. Delicious.

12 oz bottle which pours out a murky brown. green aroma of wood and malt and some alcohol heat, and caramel toast as well. the flavor matches, and the body is surprisingly lighter (as well as the finish) than i expected from a brew this big. very nice - one of a few beers that does indeed seem meant for bourbon barrel aging.

Bottle from a trade. Pours deep, dark brown with minimal head. Nose is moderate bourbon, toffee, caramel, and vanilla. Taste is similar with a TON of vanilla. This is pretty fantastic. No real alcohol warming until much later into the glass, and it is all smooth and not fusels. Probably one of the better BA beers I have had
Bottle pours clearing brown with low head. Aroma is huge sweet dark fruits and sweet bourbon, such a smooth finish, sooo good

Bottle from the brewery in Akron, OH. Poured into snifter at home. Pours a deep brown that is slightly oily with a very small beige head. Mostly opaque. No real lacing. Aroma of booze, oak barrel, vanilla, caramel and malts. The taste was quite the same with the barrel aging coming through nicely. I drank this after a Hair of the Dog Adam so it is fair to say that this is not as good. However, solid barrel aged beer.
Bottle share thanks to TJ - sweet caramel with the bourbon. Nice finish. Words

Bottle poured a very dark brown color with a coating of off white head that retained a ring on the glass. Aroma has bourbon, old oak, rich earthy malt, and underlying dark sweet fruit. Mouth feel coats well and the carbonation is good for a big barreled beer. Bottle shared by Maxxdaddy I believe. pours deep ruby. Nose is big old bourbon and toffee. tastes again super bourbony, you also get toffee, plums, maple syrup, cola, and vanilla. despite being very sweet not cloying. texture is a bit oily

Bottle thanks to Brian. Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is strong booze, oak, vanilla. Medium mouthfeel with nice light booze and strong vanilla, oak, light roast, caramel. Very good.

Pretty smooth for a 12% scotch beer. 99 percentile I do not know. Dry aged peaty. Good bourbon aroma. A bit light mouthfeel, but smooth. Very dark brown with light head and lace.
Tampa Wkly Gathering @burg326s-12oz bottle shared by Adam-still-copper. A-bourbon, sweet caramel-med malt, a bit hot. T-bourbon, sweet caramel, med malt, hop backbone.

Draft at the growler NYC . Pours a deep purple brown color. Taste is sweet and malty with a rum taste of booze and booze. More like a syrupy thick barley wine. Decent after dinner sipper

Clear dark amber pour with a deep dark ruby cast. Nice head and lacing that retains for 3 minutes. The nose is bourbon over sweet dark fruit, mostly plum and raisin, coupled with notes of vanilla, caramel and oak over molasses. Almost full bodied with a very rich creamy texture. Dark brown pour. Absolutely zero head. Aroma of vanilla, figs, dark fruit, and barrel. Taste is vanilla bean, cherries soaked in booze, wood, and caramel. This is one of the best scotch ales.
Sample from the beer cellar. Poured dark brown with min head. Killer bourbon aroma. Very smooth. Smooth bourbon taste.

Pours a thick murky brown with a creamy off white head. Aroma is nice, sweet caramel and butterscotch. Taste backs this up, along with some vanilla and a bourbony kick. Pretty sweet and super smooth.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2014 Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark brown color with orange highlights and a small foamy beige head that left a bit of lacing. Bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.). Looks good for the style; a murky dark amberish brown with thin off-white head that steadily dissipates into lacing. bottle. pours deep amber with medium white head. big sweet malt and vanilla aroma. taste matches lots of nice bourbon wood notes also this beats backwoods sorry founders :(
Bottle. Bourbon and butterscotch aroma. Really enjoyable smooth butterscotch and malt flavor. Awesome stuff.-- rated with beerbasher
Bottle. Garnet with sediment with a a small, beige head. Caramel, vanilla and bourbon. Butterscotch and butter rum.
Thanks to Adrian. Wulver is super sweet, with lots of caramel, vanilla, and bourbon. This is not for all tastes, but it might be good if youre in the mood for a dessert beer.

Poured from a 12oz bottle. I didnt realize this was a bourbon barrel aged beer, but I could definitely taste it. Aroma was boozey, flavor was awesome. Give me a 6-pack and Ill be happily drunk, very very happily, for a weekend.

12oz bottle, really solid brown looking beer, not much smoke or peat coming through which is great, not overpowered by the barrel either.. solidly balanced and flavorful not huge at 12% either doesnt taste it.
Pours chestnut brown with no head. Aroma of peat, smoke, and dark fruit. Caramel, vanilla, and dark fruit with bourbon. Slight bourbon warmth. Very nice beer. Wish I had more.

Hmmm...this is pretty serious stuff! This is for real; this is complex as it gets. This beverage hits all the marks its description says: carmel, vanilla, and tons of bourbon. This is a top-notch ale.

Bottle from George. Thanks man. Poured a bee dark brown. Darker than the typical wee heavy. Smooth vanilla, Carmel and bourbon. Scotch ale spice without the smokey peaty nonsence. This is incredibly smooth, lots I bourbon taste without any of the heat. Pretty amazing stuff.

On tap at the Ap Vintner. Beautiful dark brown color with a 1/2 inch light brown head. Nice lacing! Butterscotch flavor galore. I hope this is still available on TAP for RateBeer Winter Gathering 2014!

Bottle from HOTB. Pours a cloudy reddish brown with no head. Aroma of caramel and vanilla bourbon dark fruit. Taste is sweet with a slight bourbon heat. Oily thick mouthfeel and light carb. Very delicious.

Bottle from a quick trade. Big time thanks! Pours dark brown with very little head, which is off white and recedes quickly. Not completely opaque with some ruby showing through the edges of this one. Aroma of chocolate, bourbon, caramel, vanilla. Flavor is boozy bourbon up front alongside some sweet chocolate, then fades nicely into overwhelmingly vanilla and caramel notes. Dark brown color with small tan head. Aroma has a ton of bourbon and caramel malts. Flavor has strong bourbon kick, with sweet, creamy malts, vanilla, and a bitter cocoa. Good overall but pretty expensive.

12oz bottle - pours a dark murky brown with thin off white head . Bourbon and toffee aromas . Flavors of caramel , vanilla , brown sugar , and bourbon . Finish is very sweet . Pretty good .

pours brown with a thin white head that dissipates immediately. aroma is bourbon, vanilla, raisins, wood and smoke. aroma smells very sweet. no lacing. flavor is very sweet. bourbon, vanilla, raisins, coconut and licorice. full bodied. medium carbonation. sticky mouthfeel. finishes sweet with a very pleasant warming of the alchohol on the back of my mouth and throat. i see how some may compare this to backwoods bastard but backwoods is much more bourbon forward and not quite as sweet. non the less its a fantastic scotch ale and should be tried by all who enjoy this style.

The aroma and flavor have big caramel, vanilla, bourbon and oak. Additional notes of cherry, toffee with hints of the abv. This really drinks like a barley wine in many ways. Very tasty and would seek out if it werent for the price. We did finally get this in Ohio.
An outstanding ale, everything a great scotch ale , I would recommend this to anyone who loves a great scotch ale.

12 ounce bottle thanks to Dan. Pours a clear dark copper color with a small white head. A big nose of bourbon, vanilla, hell it smells like rum really. Bi heat, toffee, more bourbon, oak, berries, some toasted malts, caramel, a shot of heat and whiskey in this. Very warming and still quite drinkable. Great beer.
Aroma of vanilla, alcohol and caramel. A bit chewy, fairly big mouthfeel, although goes down surprisingly well. Good complexity, flavors of dark fruit, vanilla, and a warm alcohol finish.
Pours a reddish brown with big scents if vanilla and bourbon. Taste is there though a little mild. Definitely hides the alcohol well. Good stuff.

Poured from 12oz bottle. Pours cola brown with almost no head, but decent amount of carbonation. Aroma is smoked peat, caramel and rye. Taste is slightly sweet, notes of toffee and some burnt sugar. Tasty stuff. Reminds me a lot of Backwoods Bastard. Tasty stuff.

Boy Howdy! This is one damn fine sipper. Brilliant clear brown with ring of light tan head and coolaid red highlights. Sweet caramel and vanilla notes with biscuit and raisin and hints of plum. Sweet but not cloying. Smooth and sticky on the palate. Surprisingly, it really doesnt have a massive booziness or heat to it. Hides the abv very well. The bourbon is very well done. Not over bearing. Not invisible. Just the right amount. Really nice!

Bottle from Dennis, thanks!
Dark amber/brown with a small beige head, no retention.
Wow, heavy on the caramel/fudge, vanilla and bourbon in both aroma and taste.
Taste also has some wood and sweet liquorice as well and ends with a slight alcohol heat. Very well balanced. Full body, medium carbonation and smooth non cloying/coating mouth feel.
(12oz bottle) Pours a clear copper body with a spare off-white head. Aroma of bourbon, wood, brown sugar, and coconut. Flavor of caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, toffee, bourbon, and wood.

This is the one of the best BA Scotch Ale Ive had. Thirsty Dog really set a new standard for BA scotch ales with this beer. For me, it beats out Backwoods by just a little. I had them side by side, and I felt the Wulver was just a little better. It was also very hard to compare though, since both are world class beers.

Brown pour with a tan head. The aroma has some strong bourbon notes with a lot of maple, vanilla and peat malt character. The flavor is similar. The Scotch and peat notes come through up front, but are complimented by a heavy dose of bourbon character. I get a lot of maple, oak, vanilla and whiskey notes that really add to the base beer. Thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Really liked this one.

Bottle shared thanks to JB ! Pours a rich dark rusty caramel color with a a finger of khaki foam. Lots of sweet butterscotch and caramel, burnt toffee, toasted malt and some boozy heat. The palate follows... rich creamy werthers candy, vanilla, spicy oak, cinnamon and a touch of burnt earthiness. Long smooth finish.
Darkish caramel colored hue, toffee / burnt sugar aroma & taste. Smooth, creamy, sweet, yet refined taste definitely isn't cloying. I'm a fan.

12oz to snifter. Pours deep amber/tawny with a thin ring of lace. A few bubbles stick around. Aromas of candied fruit, vanilla, oak, bourbon, plum, and huge caramel. Damn this smells awesome. Smooth and delightful body to this. Gobs of caramel, vanilla, candy, warming booze, huge malt, and finishing full. A touch of carbonation cleans up the finish, while caramel notes linger. Nice presence of the barrel, but not overwhelming....just right. Stellar brew, just fucking stellar!

A vinous amber-prune pour, with a fully retentive head that leaves no lacing of which to speak. A gorgeously sweet vanilla-caramel, figgy, vinous nose ensues. A bit of toasted caramel, tons of vanilla, bourbon accents, raisins, figs, breadiness, toffee, pitted fruits and a touch of alcohol combine to form a really nice after-dinner sipper. A bourbon-vanilla caramel finishes the pull nicely. The full body and light diacetyl alcoholic mouthfeel provide a comforting "late night" aperitif feel to this complex aged offering.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep caramel, thin sudsy off-white head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Bourbony nose, caramel malts, a little bready. &nbsp Nice aroma, but not as complex as other BA beers. &nbsp Soft caramal malt and bourbon start. &nbsp This is 12%? &nbsp Doesnt even feel like 6%. &nbsp Easy to drink, but again, not complex. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Light vanilla, caramel, with more bourbon on the finish. &nbsp Not real chewy or heavy, and thankfully not sticky. &nbsp Its also nice that it doesnt drink like a 12% beer at all, but its also pretty simple overall. &nbsp Is it a Scotch Ale? &nbsp No clue... pretty simplistic overall. &nbsp Thanks Kevin!

My Bottom Line :  
Vanilla, aniseed and fruit jam are laced in alcohol warmth in this silky and surprisingly elegant Barrel-Aged Scotch Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A ring of foam crowns the shiny dark amber.
-The nose is a tad linear (all bourbon).
-The residual sugar level is kept in check. This is rich, but nowhere near as obese as some big Scotch Ales tend to be.
-The chosen malts and bourbon barrels are perfectly harmonious.
-This is one of those rare beers that works best around room temperature. All flavors just become perfectly cohesive.

Bottle.

12 ounce bottle from Bestway. Pours a clear cranberry color with a thin tan head. Fair head retention. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, raisin, caramel, wood. The taste is caramel, toffee, vanilla, whisky, wood, dark fruits. Medium bodied, alcohol assertive, but not hot and well balanced. Nice beer.
Bottle thanks to jstax..Pour is dark brown with a off white head..Nose is toffee, spice, bourbon, oak, caramel , vanilla..Taste is spices, caramel, fig, brown sugar, bourbon, alcohol..light mouth

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass; no bottle dating, but was a recent release. Pours moderately hazy and cloudy deep ruby red color with a small fairly dense off white head with decent retention, that reduces to a thin lace that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big caramel, toast, toffee, raisin, brown bread, vanilla, clove, oak, molasses, light chocolate, pepper, light roast, and toasted earthiness. Incredible aromas with amazing complexity and balance of malt and barrel notes; with good strength. Taste of big caramel, toast, toffee, raisin, vanilla, clove, oak, bourbon, brown bread, molasses, chocolate, light roast, and toasted earthiness. Lingering notes of caramel, toast, toffee, raisin, brown bread, vanilla, clove, oak, bourbon, chocolate, light roast, and toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity of malt and barrel flavors; with absolutely perfect balance of barrel/malt and zero cloying sweetness on the finish. Light-medium carbonation and full bodied; with a creamy, slick, and lightly syrupy mouthfeel that is fantastic. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is an absolutely world class barrel aged scotch ale. All around insane complexity and balance of malt and barrel flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the ABV. Amazing.

Aroma: Vanilla, waffle cone, chocolate, toffee. Appearance: Murky dark brown with light tan head. Flavor: Matches the nose; mostly barrel character with little reference to the base beer, but enjoyable. Palate: Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation, long finish. Overall: Outside of Siberian Night, probably their best beer.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle, compliments of JStax, poured into a tulip. Pours dark brown with dark amber highlight at bottom, and small beige head. Aroma is rich caramel malt aroma, thick body, no carbonation, and thin small bubble lacing. Taste is rich sweet molasses, bourbon, oak, with a hint of alcohol. Nice sipper.

Via trade with Spence3208. The aroma is bourbon, fruit, bread, smoke. The appearance is dep brown/amber, red hue, off-white head. The flavor is booze, fruit, caramel. The finish is boozy, sweet. Medium/thick in body. Nice.
Pricey ($20+ for a 4 pack) but worth every penny. Perfect balance of bourbon barrel and beer tastes.

Pours a nice clear brown/amber color with minimal head. Aroma is very malty/bouirbon heavy with maybe some caramel and vanilla. Flavor is bourbon forward but a nice sweet malt to balance possibly earthy notes with wood, caramel, vanilla. Finish is a little alcohol heavy with bourbon and malt. Mouthfeel is acidic and medium. Carbonation is low-average. Overall this is a delicious beer.

Bottle from Capones. Poured mahogany with minimal head. Nose is heavy bourbon, some honey, dark fruit, maple syrup, molasses. Tastes very oaky, bourbony, with notes of honey, nuts, and a sort of cognacy finish. Dense and complex palate. This is an outstanding beer, although the oak and bourbon aging have removed most of the Wee Heavy characteristics, as such.

Bottle from Tim. Enjoyed this tremendously. Smooth and alcoholic at the same time. Wasn't as rich as it warmed but still yummy

Bottle: caramel, molasses, fruit, bourbon, vanilla, and fain coconut. It pours a dark brown with some orange transparency . It has a small beige head that leaves behind some sporadic lacing. The flavor starts with caramel, molasses, toffee, and candied fruits. The finish has bourbon, light vanilla, oak, and a touch of coconut. Its medium bodied with mild carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid BA Scotch Ale.

From a lovely gold-foiled 12oz bottle. 

Pours dark with little head with nice lacing. Sweet ale aroma and taste. Interesting addition of the BBL. not sure if the BBL adds enough to offset the undesirable sweetness of the wee ale.

Nice thicker brew, great mourthfeel. Caramel and spice a good mont of bourbon barrel.

Pours deep brown and ruby, clear.....with a thin, off-white ring.
Aroma is vanilla, bourbon, sugar, bread.
Flavour is chocolate, vanilla, caramel-toffee.
Wonderful bourbon heat and taste.
Alcohol is nicely masked
This is a big, bold beer.
Wonderful.
What a brew!! Bourbon aroma and flavor, warming mouthfeel, toffee and sweet malt finish.

What can I say that the bottle does not. This beer was made for aging in bourbon barrels. get warming bourbon taste. Lots of Vanilla and caramel. very little carbonation that dissipates quickly. Ill be purchasing more of these wonderful sippers to cellar!

Smaller than expected aroma with a dark pour, balanced taste and small warming mouthfeel.

Pours medium brown, slight off white head light lacing. Aroma is big bready, sweet toffee, lots of bourbon, slight oak. Taste is bready, vanilla, caramel, toffee, bourbon, brown sugar. Medium full body, medium carbonation, a lot of alcohol heat, sweet finish. Overall really good, not sure if it?s worth the $5.99/12 oz asking price, but every once in a while for sure.

Gave this a try at $6.25 a 12oz bottle. Not my thing. Heavy on the smell and taste of bourbon. Wood, vanilla, and roasted malts also come thru on the aroma and palate. Sipper that is just a little too heavy for me. This was a big swing and miss. Oh well, live and learn.

This one poured a lighter brown color with an off white head. Aroma was of lots of bourbon, wood, caramel, dark fruits, and alcohol. Flavor was similar, lightly hot, but not burning, lots of vanilla, wood, and caramel, with some figs and chocolate in there too. Complex and tasty. Reminded me a lot of Alesmith BA Wee Heavy.

disclaimer: I generally love barrel aged beers. this is an outstanding barrelled beer. there is a little bit of bourbon heat in the finish. lots of vanilla creamy sweetness through out. notes on the bottle say the beer was designed/brewed to be barrel aged and I can tell. it just seems to bring out the best in the wood.
12 oz bottle. Clear purple brown with off-white foam. Nose is bourbon, grape, wood and dates. Medium body with a sharp tang. Taste is mostly bourbon with hints of scotch and rock candy.

12 ounce bottle. Served in a thistle glass, the beer pours a mostly clear reddish/brown color with about an inch light tan head that stayed around for a while. Theres also a good amount of lacing. Aroma is very sweet, the brew smells like caramel, bourbon, vanilla, brown sugar, dark fruit, and molasses. The taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but with the addition of some nuts and a bit of chocolate. Its a very sweet tasting brew full of malty goodness! Mouthfeel/body is medium, its slick, smooth and very easy to drink. It certainly doesnt drink like a 12% ABV brew. I think this is a pretty good brew overall. Yeah, its pricey at $23.99 a 4-pack, but its tasty and I dont regret buying it. Luckily I have 3 bottles left! Worth trying for sure!

Bottle. Pours a dark ruby red color with a small fizzy/foamy head that quickly fades to a ring. Big barrel notes in the aroma but the bourbon remains subtle. Vanilla, wood, light bourbon, cocoa, caramel, plums, and toffee. Taste is pretty impressive. Im not usually a big scotch ale person. Sweet caramel is balanced nicely with the barrel. Lots of dark fruit in the finish, pretty boozy too. Medium body, fairly sticky mouthfeel. Overall, this was a really good sipper. Right up there with AleSmith as my favorite scotch ale Ive tried.

12oz bottle. Poured a dark amber, almost brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of wood, vanilla, caramel, and lighter bourbon. Tastes of wood, caramel, peat, bourbon, and vanilla. Overall the alcohol content well hidden.

Wow! Outstanding beer! I loved the imperial stout version, but this one blew it away! Aroma was perfect. Strong vanilla, roasted malt and bourbon. Pour was a nice deep dark amber with a thin off white film for a head. Taste was near perfect. A strong mix of vanilla, caramel and toffee sweetness with a nice sweet wet finish. One of the best bourbon barrel aged beers Ive had. Mild carbonation.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2013 12oz bottle 2013. Very thin brown pour with a wisp of head. Nose is typical of the style with sweet caramel, booze, vanilla, and a touch of peat. Taste follows the nose. The bourbon and the beer dont meld as well as others BB Scotch Ales I have had. I think this may be more related to the thinness of the beer. All in all good but not in the same class as others

Bottle from Charleston Beer Exchange. Pours dark brown with tan head ring. Nose and taste of bourbon, vanilla, oak, plum, dark fruit, toffee, sweet brown sugar and caramelized sugar. A touch sweeter than Id like. Still, solid beer. Full body.

Bottle from mikem409, thanks man. Pours a mostly clear dirty red with a little head. Bourbon, toffee, oak on the nose, flavor is similar but with some chocolate mixed it. Really a good beer, would buy every bottle offered.

Bottle @ MPLS LOL tasting, courtesy of my Minnesota friends. Thanks Kyle! Pours a fairly clear, reddish brown appearance with a light tan head. Sweet bourbon, toffee, big vanilla, oaky, slight candy aroma. Somewhat spicy, cinnamon, rich toffee, light chocolate, thick chocolate, bourbon flavor. Smooth and delicious.
Bourbon and malty nose. Clear caramel color. Light, smooth, really lovely. Big caramel and vanilla in this. Thanks Hoff!!

Clean garnet copper brown pour with two fingers of very thin tan head.  Nose is a touch boozy and super rich.  Slightly singular, dextrinous malt with burnt sugar and bourbon barrel.  Lots of vanillin and wood.  Lots of caramel and burnt sugar with vanillin and alcohol showing big time on the finish.  Very rich and bourbon. Candyish.  Enjoyed.

Wow. This must be made using fine bourbon barrels, the first aroma. Aroma is intricate and tart with a snuff of molasses at the tail. Appearance is perfect for the style -- as if its more watery on the outside and harboring a core of flavor and substance. Taste is sublime. Just the perfect bourbon barrel-aged old ale flavor.

12 oz bottle, part of $23.99 4-pack, thanks Ryan.  Clear, very dark garnet-like brown pour; quarter-inch minimal tan fizzy head dissipates into nothing fairly quickly.  Aroma... Wow.  Booze, alcohol, bourbon, oak, vanilla, spice, caramel, brown sugar, pepper, bubble gum, tiny hint of smoke or peat; I could revel in this smell for days.  Flavor is slightly less complex but very nice; the 12% abv shows but isnt overwhelming; bourbon and oak are apparent, lots of booze and caramel, loads of brown sugary malt and absolutely no bitterness.  Big, full, sticky, sweet body.  Really nice.

On draft at the Brew Kettle.  Pours a hazy brown copper color with an off-white head.  Nose is some sweet malt, maple, bourbon, toffee, and some vanilla.  Flavor is a nice blend of bourbon, sweet malt, toffee, and vanilla with lingering vanilla and bourbon into the finish.  Medium in body and no idea it was 10%.  Very nice BA Wee Heavy.

32oz growler from greenville beer exchange. pours a deep, dark copper capped by a thin, whispy, off-white head that leaves a tight ring of lace. aroma is excellent with heavy notes of toffee, caramel candies, vanilla, peat smoke, and cocoa backed by toasted barrel, black cherries, and figs. flavor is wonderful as well with more sweet caramel, toffee, vanilla beans, oak, and bourbon up front with honey, raisins, figs, and a hint of cocoa and espresso on the finish. palate is full bodied with light carbonation and a dry, woody, sweet finish. damn nice barrel aged scotch here.
Brown pour.  Aroma of bourbon, oak barrels, light peat, dark toffee.  Flavor is rich and full.  Lots of vanilla, caramel, oak, toffee.  Good barrel notes.  Rich and nice.
Dark brown pour with frothy tan head. Bourbon aroma with sweet malt and earthy tones. Sweet but quickly followed by dark chocolate coating. Lingers in the mouth for awhile. Full Body.

Draft. Poured a hazy dark brown color with a moderate to large frothy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Medium to heavy toasted malt, wood and earthy bourbon aroma. Medium to full body with a creamy smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bourbon sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. A smooth complex drinkable brew.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2013 Sampled on tap. Clear red / brown color. Good even off-white head. Full-coverage lace. Really sweet barrel-woody taste. Woody aroma, lots of caramel. Very light carbonation, big body. Maybe not the best choice in this very hot environment. Decent, but not my thing.. too sweet 6/4/5/3/12 Re-rate, 7/15/13: 12oz bottle, shared by Dan H. So, so much more tasty and complex this time around. Fantastic nose. Vanilla, butterscotch, some marzipan. Plum, toasted coconut. Bit of chocolate. Clear red orange color. Minimal light khaki head. Couple loose dots of lace. Good, moderate sweet taste, lightly spicy, tasty alcohol warmth. No cloy, no alcohol burn. Very nice long aftertaste to savor the complex aroma. Bit of burnt sugar, little brown sugar. Bigger body, very light carbonation. Smooth, creamy texture. Excellent stuff. Tastiest, most complex scotch ale I think Ive ever had.

Poured on draft. Appearance is dark ruby to brown with a thin beige head of foam. Not much retention. Aroma is light oaky vanilla, woody, barrel notes with a nice showing of the peaty earthy leathery notes of the base beer. Lots of peat and earthy notes are coming through in this one. Taste is initially full on bourbon, but it really becomes a nicely delicate flavor that allows the base beer to shine. I like how Thirsty Dog is doing their barrel aging program, making the heat of the spirits more of a secondary flavor than an in your face flavor.

Beautiful caramel color, silky smooth. aroma of oak and vanilla, alcohol is present as it should be with the style. Really nice, I'm not a wee heavy fan but this is really nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Growler This beer rocks! Pours deep, dark and clear with a mahogany sparkle when held up to light. The aromatic high-points are singed caramel, vanilla, a splash of bourbon and a hint of acidity. Full-bodied and silky with soft carbonation. The flavor leans sweet, but is well-balanced overall. Nice caramel, vanilla and bourbon components. Lengthy, bittersweet finish. Thanks to Elliesbrown for shipping this growler of world class beer to me!
Ba scotch ale, pours a ruby red, tastes sweet with hints of vanilla and caramel. This is quite good.

Nose of scotch, alcohol, sweet malt. Chocolate color, light colored head. Thick mouthfeel, long alcohol burn finish. Alcohol very much preset throughout. Malt heavy to balance the high alcohol. Bourbon barrel, caramel and scotch.

On tap at Thirsty Dog.  Pours dark brown with brown sugar head.  Aroma is burnt brown sugar, wood, oak, vanilla, bourbon, and alcohol fusel.  Mouthfeel is tingly from a touch of carbonation and alcohol.  Flavors pretty much follow the nose with some raisins and dark fruit sneaking in.  Its pretty hot.  Overall a vanilla and bourbon bomb to be exact.  I dig it.

Winking Lizard Cask Ale Fest 2011 (3/26/11) from notes: pours dark brown. caramel malts, oak, bourbon, subtle dark fruits, esters. vanilla and distinct nuttiness flavors. thought this was well done and one of the better beers available on this day.

Tap at hopcat. Dark brown pour with medium-sized tan, creamy head to match the equally soft and creamy mouthfeel. Aroma of hot, spicy hops with some burnt sugar and raisin. Flavor is much more elaborate, with the barrel coming through in a wonderful way. Big in resinous hops, pine, dark fruit, and vanilla with a bit of heat in the finish. Good stuff.

On cask at the Winking Lizard 3rd Annual Real Ale Fest 3/26/11. Cloudy brown pour with a minimal beige head. Lovely nose of caramel, cherry, oak and bourbon. Caramelly and peaty (but not overly peaty) malt flavor giving way to cherry and almond before an oaky vanilla finish.

Cask version at Winking Lizards 3rd Annual Real Ale Fest (03/26/11): This beer is a murky reddish brown color with a minimal off-white head that disappears quickly. Spotty lacing. Aroma of dark fruit, malt and oak. Rich, syrupy body with flavors of earthy malt, fruit, caramel and oak. The finish is oaky vanilla with a lingering bourbon aftertaste. Pretty good  overall.
